line: Own brands growth is a major trend in the recent evolution of distribution. In 1995, own brands provided
label: paragraph

line: on average 20% of sales (25% of shelf space) compared to only 10% ten years before and the development
label: paragraph

line: goes on. Leclerc, for instance, which was initially opposed to own brand development (less than 7% of
label: paragraph

line: sales before 1997 were own brand), changed its strategy in 1997 and its goal is now to double its own
label: paragraph

line: brands turnover. Retailers try to reinforce the association between their name and their own products.
label: paragraph

line: As noted above, retailers set higher margins on own brands than on other brands even if retail prices are
label: paragraph

line: lower. According to ICC 95, the mark up rate fixed by retailers is estimated on average at 23% of the
label: paragraph

line: turnover for own brands, 15% for low price products and 14.5% for national brands. Moreover, shelf
label: paragraph

line: space profitability is higher: if the gross mark-up per square meter of shelf space index is 100 then own
label: paragraph

line: brands profitability is 123, low price items profitability is 63 and national brands profitability is 103.
label: paragraph

line: 8.5 Internationalisation
label: heading

line: Internationalisation has been an important feature of French hypermarket and supermarket chains. There
label: paragraph

line: are two main reasons why such internationalisation exists. First, the French food retail market is fairly
label: paragraph

line: saturated, and, in particular with the Raffarin law recently introduced, future hypermarket or supermarket
label: paragraph

line: growth within France is more difficult. Second, international subsidiaries tend to be more profitable than
label: paragraph

line: domestic ones, particularly in countries in southern (or eastern) Europe where large store development lags
label: paragraph

line: behind. In fact, French companies began moving into other countries in the early 1970’s and this process
label: paragraph

line: has continued ever since.
label: paragraph

line: Table 8.15 shows foreign turnover by leading retail groups in 1997. Much of the expansion has been
label: paragraph

line: undertaken by Carrefour (which also acquired Comptoirs Modernes in 1997 and has a 41% stake in Cora),
label: paragraph

line: Promodès and Auchan. Carrefour, for example, opened its first hypermarket ‘Pryca’ in Spain in 1973 (in
label: paragraph

line: Barcelona) and now has 56 ‘Pryca’ stores. Promodès moved into Spain in 1976 and now has 52
label: paragraph

line: hypermarkets ‘Continente’, l,830 discount stores ‘Dia’ and 33 cash and carrys ‘Puntocash’. Non-
label: paragraph

line: integrated groups such as Leclerc have been slower to start International development although Leclerc
label: paragraph

line: now has 11 stores abroad.
label: paragraph

line: group.
label: paragraph

line: Greece and Italy offer real growth prospects to the extent that a strict legislative system has delayed retail
label: paragraph

line: trade evolution for a long time. East European countries, which represent 70 million consumers, offer new
label: paragraph

line: outlets for the largest French groups. In particular, Poland is an emerging market with an underdeveloped
label: paragraph

line: market structure and growing consumers’ buying power. Casino, Auchan and also some non-integrated
label: paragraph

line: groups have already begun to settle in Poland. As this trend continues, companies such as Carrefour and
label: paragraph

line: Promodès will look increasingly to buying supplies on an European (or even global) level, and this will
label: paragraph

line: heighten the buying power of such groups.
label: paragraph

line: 8.6 Products
label: heading

line: 8.6.1 Washing Powders and Detergents
label: paragraph

line: The market for washing products in France represents 60% of the detergents’ market. It is quite strongly
label: paragraph

line: segmented, as each brand exists in several formats (standard powder, liquid, concentrated, and recently
label: paragraph

line: tablets) and in various container sizes. This segmentation is a central issue in the negotiations between
label: paragraph

line: producers and retailers: producers develop innovations to bring about market growth, and they create a
label: paragraph

line: number of new reference points, whereas retailers face increasing difficulties in handling this product
label: paragraph

line: proliferation and the ensuing complexity of the range of products. More particularly, the launching of
label: paragraph

line: compact powders initially suited both producers and retailers because of the potential growth it offered and
label: paragraph

line: because of the decrease of logistic costs it was supposed to bring. Yet it did not seem to suit consumers,
label: paragraph

line: since nearly 50% of them now still buy standard powder, as shown in Table 8.16. The number of reference
label: paragraph

line: points listed by retailers has thus increased: there are
label: paragraph

line: hypermarket, and about 85 in the average supermarket.
label: paragraph
